Co3O4 species in Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst can be tailored to smaller particle size and higher content of surface lattice O2− and Co3+ species by pre-reduction and pre-oxidation (labeled as Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst), resulting in the enhanced catalytic activity for propane combustion. The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst gives a high reaction rate of 0.379 μmol gcat −1 s−1, which is over two folds higher than that of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst (reaction rate of only 0.177 μmol gcat −1 s−1). The higher content and reducibility of surface lattice O2− in the Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst facilitated its activity for propane combustion through the Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism as evidenced by in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectra. The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst (Ea = 37.1 ± 2.9 kJ mol−1) gives much lower apparent activation energy than 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst (Ea = 85.5 ± 6.7 kJ mol−1), suggesting the easier occurrence of propane combustion over the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. The atmospheres (2% O2 + 0.2% C3H8 + N2; 9% O2 + 0.2% C3H8 + N2; Air) for pre-oxidation process also significantly affect the catalytic activity of the finally obtained catalysts (labeled as 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C), which is attributed to their differences in Co3O4 species (nanoparticle size, and the content of surface lattice O2− and Co3+). Besides, the acid sites of ZSM-5 also play important role on the catalytic combustion propane. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Propane combustion Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst Co3+ species Surface lattice O2− 1 Introduction Up to date, the issues of environmental pollution caused by volatile organic compounds (VOCs) emission have drawn much attention, and there is in an urgent need to develop efficient technologies for the abatement of VOCs because of the increasingly stringent environmental legislation [1–4]. The available technologies mainly include adsorption and combustion, etc. Catalytic combustion is widely regarded as one of the most promising method for eliminating VOCs due to its high efficiency and low cost, especially for the low concentration and stable VOCs [5,6]. Light alkanes, such as propane, are the representative stable VOCs which are often employed as model reactants for the benchmark of the catalysts. Substantial release of propane in the field of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) also urgently demand the efficient elimination method [7]. Although noble metal based catalysts (e.g., Pt and Pd) are effective for VOCs combustion, their large-scale commercial application is limited by their high cost, easy poisoning as well as sintering [8–10]. Therefore, the development of cheap and efficient non-noble metal catalyst is a promising alternative [11,12]. The non-noble metal catalysts for VOCs combustion mainly include the transition metal oxides such as Co3O4, MnOx, CuO, etc [13–17]. Among them, Co3O4 with a spinel structure is potential because of its high activity. Luo et al. reported that the Co3O4-CeO2 catalyst presented higher activity than CuO-CeO2 catalyst for propane combustion, because the propane molecule could be easily activated on neighboring surface lattice oxygen sites in Co3O4 species [18]. Ma et al. found that the Co3O4 nanorods were more active than the Pt/Al2O3 catalyst for propane combustion at high space velocity [19]. In addition, various methods were reported to improve the activities of Co3O4 catalysts. For instance, Liao et al. adjusted the synergistic roles of surface acidity and reducibility of Co3O4-Cr2O3 catalyst to enhance its catalytic activity for propane combustion, and the catalyst with a Co/Cr molar ratio of 1/2 (1Co2Cr) possessed the highest activity with reaction rate of 1.38 μmol g−1 s−1 at 250 °C) [20]. Zhu et al. found the Co3+ content and migration of the lattice oxygen in Co3O4 species could be tuned by preparing Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalysts with different methods (impregnation, deposition precipitation, hydrothermal method), resulting in the remarkably different catalytic activities [21]. Cai et al. adopted the reduction-passivation treatment for enhancing Co3O4/γ-Al2O3 catalyst activity, which could generate the higher dispersed active cobalt oxides with a stable core-shell structure (Co3O4@CoO and Co3O4@CoO@Co) [22]. Although much progress has been made, there are still some key issues to be addressed urgently, such as debatable active sites of Co3O4 catalysts. Many works propose that Co3+ and surface lattice oxygen are crucial active sites for propane combustion [18,21], while it was also reported that Co2+ cations are active for propane combustion [11,23]. Herein, we reported a simple but effective method to improve the performance of Co3O4 catalyst for propane combustion. A supported Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst treated by sequential reduction and oxidation exhibited much improved activity and the underlining mechanism was discussed based on detailed characterizations, which is meaningful for the development of efficient Co3O4 based catalysts. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of pristine Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalysts and pre-reduced catalysts The supported Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst was prepared by a typical impregnation method. Zeolite ZSM-5 (with a Si/Al molar ratio of 18) support was purchased from Shandong Dengzhuo Chemical Co., Ltd. China, and cobalt precursor (Co(NO3)2·6H2O) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. China. Taking the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst as an example, 1.233 g Co(NO3)2·6H2O (with a Co content of 0.25 g) was dissolved in deionized water (5 mL), then 1 g ZSM-5 was added and stirred for 1.5 h at room temperature. Afterwards, the mixture was evaporated on a water bath at 90 °C, and the obtained solid was dried at 120 °C for 12 h and calcined at 500 °C for 3 h. Other catalysts with different Co contents were prepared in a similar manner and denoted as xCo3O4/ZSM-5, where x represents the Co weight percentage to ZSM-5 support. The actual contents of Co3O4 in the catalysts were summarized in Table S1. The obtained xCo3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst was reduced by high purity H2 (99.99 %, 30 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 2 h, and was denoted as xCo3O4/ZSM-5-R. 2.2 Treatments of xCo3O4/ZSM-5-R catalysts The xCo3O4/ZSM-5-R catalyst was subsequently pre-oxidized under different atmospheres from 20 to 480 °C with a heating rate of 20 °C min−1, and then was cooled down to room temperature. The obtained catalysts were designated as shown in Table 1 . The 25Co3O4/CeO2-A and 25Co3O4/Al2O3-A catalysts are also prepared according to the method for synthesis of Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. 2.3 Characterizations The XRD patterns of the Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalysts were recorded on a Bruker D8 diffractometer using Cu Kα radiation operating at 40 kV and 40 mA with a scan speed of 12 min−1 from 2θ of 10 to 90 o. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were conducted on an ESCALAB 250Xi instrument with Al Kα source and the binding energy was calibrated by C1s (284.8 eV). H2-temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) and NH3-temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) experiments were conducted on a lab-made reactor. The process of H2-TPR was performed at a temperature of 30 to 800 °C at a heating rate of 20 °C min−1 (in a flow of 5% H2 + 95% N2, 30 mL min−1). The signal was recorded using a TCD detector. For the NH3-TPD, 200 mg of the catalyst (60–80 mesh) was loaded in a tubular reactor and heated in N2 flow (20 mL min−1) from 30 to 300 °C (with a rate of 10 °C min−1) and kept at 300 °C for 30 min, and then cooled down to 50 °C. Afterward, an NH3 flow (99.9%, 30 mL min−1) was introduced to the reactor for 10 min. Then, the sample was purged by a N2 flow (99.99 %, 20 mL min−1) for 30 min to remove gaseous or physically adsorbed NH3. Afterwards, the catalyst was heated in a N2 flow (99.99 %, 20 mL min−1) from 40 to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1, and the signal of desorbed NH3 was recorded by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The signal was also recorded using a TCD detector. Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) test was conducted on Bruker EPR EMXplus under 9.8 GHZ. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy (DRIFTS) investigations for propane oxidation were performed on a Thermal-Fischer Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer equipped with a MCT detector. 20 mg of catalyst was loaded in a PIKE DRIFT accessory and was pre-treated in N2 purge at 280 °C for 30 min, and background spectra were recorded. Then, a mixed flow of 0.2 vol.% C3H8 +99.8 vol.% N2 (30 mL min−1) was introduced for 30 min at 280 °C, followed by another mixed flow of 0.2 vol.% C3H8 + 2 vol.% O2 + 97.8 vol. % N2 (30 mL min−1) for 30 min. Lastly, the N2 purge flow was introduced for 30 min and the spectra were recorded. 2.4 Catalytic activity evaluation The activities of the catalysts for propane combustion were measured in a tubular quartz reactor (i.d. = 6 mm). Typically, the catalyst (50 mg, 60–80 mesh) diluted by 50 mg quartz sand was put in the reactor. A gas mixture containing 0.2 vol.% C3H8 + 2 vol.% O2 + 97.8 vol.% N2 was introduced to the catalyst bed with a flow of 66.6 mL min−1 (a mass space velocity of 80000 mL g−1 h−1). The concentrations of propane in the inlet and outlet were detected by a gas chromatography (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a DB-Wax (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) capillary column and FID detector. Propane conversion can obtained by the following formula: Conversion = ( [ C ] in − [ C ] out ) / [ C ] in × 100 % . [C]in and [C]out Cin and Cout were the propane concentration in the inlet and outlet of reactor, respectively. Reaction kinetics over Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalysts were performed at differential reaction condition (with propane conversion below 15%), see Supporting Information. The catalyst was diluted with quartz sand (with same size) to 100 mg, and it was aged under the same condition as in catalytic test. By adjusting the partial pressures of propane (0.202–0.808 kPa) and O2 (9.09–1.515 kPa) in the reaction gas, a series of reaction rates were obtained and related kinetic parameters were derived. The detailed data of Arrhenius plots are also given in Supporting Information for calculating apparent activation energy (Ea). The absence of mass and heat transfer limitations was verified by the calculation of Weisz-Prater and Mears’ criterion, see Supporting Information. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic testing for propane combustion The catalytic activities of propane combustion over the Co3O4/ZSM-5 and Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 , and the content of Co3O4 in catalysts are summarized in Table S1. For the Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalysts, the catalytic activity gradually increases and reaches the maximum at the 25 Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst, and then decreases at higher Co3O4 content (Fig. 1a). The reaction rates at 250 °C are shown in Fig. 1c, and the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst exhibits the highest reaction rate of 0.177 μmol gcat −1 s−1. It is interesting that the Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts are much more active than the corresponding Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalysts with the same content of Co3O4. For instance, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst gives a reaction rate of 0.379 μmol gcat −1 s−1 but only 0.177 μmol gcat −1 s−1 for the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst. In contrary, the Co3O4 catalyst (0.081 μmol gcat −1 s−1) shows a slightly higher activity than the Co3O4-A catalyst (0.060 μmol gcat −1 s−1). It should be noted that all the Co3O4/ZSM-5 and Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts are more active than the Co3O4 and Co3O4-A catalysts, indicating the important roles of ZSM-5 support in the reaction. Besides, the content of Co3O4 also affect the catalytic activity of Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts as observed on the Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalysts (Fig. 1b and c). The catalytic activities of 25Co3O4/CeO2-A and 25Co3O4/Al2O3-A catalysts are also slightly improved compared to the 25Co3O4/CeO2 and 25Co3O4/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. S1), respectively, which further confirms the modification strategy is efficient for improving the catalytic activity of Co3O4 based catalyst. Fig. 2 shows the performance of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C catalysts. The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst gives the lowest T80 (the reaction temperature for propane conversion of 80%) of 280 °C. In Fig. 2b, the reaction rates of these catalysts at 250 °C follow an order of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A (0.379 μmol gcat −1 s−1) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B (0.251 μmol gcat −1 s−1) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C (0.181 μmol gcat −1 s−1) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 (0.177 μmol gcat −1 s−1). Among them, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst gives an activity over two folds higher than that of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst. The catalysts in the current work are among the best ones reported in literature [21–27] (Table 2 ). Particularly, the 5Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst gives a high specific rate of 2.65 μmol gCo3O4 −1 s−1 at 250 °C. Fig. 3 shows the stability test of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst for propane oxidation. The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst could give very stable activity with propane conversion of ca. 80% under dry condition at 280 °C for 25 h (Fig. 3a), indicating that its active sites are robust during the propane combustion reaction. Thus, the above results confirm that the method provided in this work could indeed construct the efficient and stable Co3O4 based catalysts for propane combustion. However, the activity of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst would remarkably decrease from the dry to wet condition (5% H2O) for propane combustion (Fig. 3b), which may be ascribed to the competitive adsorption of H2O molecular with propane on the Co3O4 species surface. The catalytic activity of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst could return to the original level once the water vapor is cut off, implying the deactivation caused by water vapor adsorption is reversible. 3.2 Characterizations of the catalysts To explain the enhanced activities on the Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts, the following discussion is focused on the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C catalysts due to their equivalent contents of Co3O4 (ca. 25 wt.%). The XRD patterns and the SEM images of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . The characteristic diffractions at 2θ of 31.3, 36.8, 59.3 and 65.2o are observed for all these catalysts (Fig. 4a), which are assigned to the crystal faces of (220), (311), (511) and (440) for spinel Co3O4 (JCPDS No. 42-1467), respectively [21,34]. Significant differences in the intensities of the features of Co3O4 species in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C catalysts indicate different sizes of Co3O4 species in catalysts. The crystallite sizes of the Co3O4 nanoparticles in the catalysts are calculated by the Scherrer equation (Table 3 ), which follows an order of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 (24.4 nm) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C (23.2 nm) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B (21.1 nm) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A (13.9 nm). Thus, the atmospheres for oxidizing the Co3O4/ZSM-5-R have significant effects on the size of Co3O4 species. Among them, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst obtained by pre-oxidizing the Co3O4/ZSM-5-R in the propane mixture atmosphere (2% O2 + 0.2% C3H8 + N2) gave the smallest size of Co3O4 species of 13.4 nm. Fig. 4c and d shows the SEM images of the Co3O4/ZSM-5 and Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts, the Co3O4 nanoparticles could be easily observed on the catalysts surface. And the nanoparticles size of Co3O4 species in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst is indeed larger than that of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst, which is consistent with XRD result. The above results confirms that highly dispersed Co3O4 species were obtained in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst compared to the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst. The size of Co3O4 species in catalysts are also analyzed during the preparation of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst (Fig. 4b, Table 3). The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-R catalyst gives weak diffractions at 44.4 and 75.8o, which are assigned to metallic cobalt with cubic phase (JCPDS No. 15-0806) [28]. The size of metallic cobalt is 23.7 nm calculated by Scherrer equation. Such observation implies that the Co3O4 species in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 are entirely reduced to metallic cobalt species by H2. After the pre-oxidation of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-R in propane mixture atmosphere (2% O2 + 0.2% C3H8 + N2), Co3O4 species can be observed in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst, which has a smaller crystallite size compared to that in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst (Fig. 4b and Table 3), suggesting that Co3O4 specie would restructure on the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst surface after the reduction and subsequent oxidation process. Besides, the avarege size of the Co3O4 species in the spent 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A slightly increases (from 13.9 to 20.7 nm) because of the thermal aggregation during the reaction at high temperature, whereas the activity remains as shown in Fig. 3. Fig. 5 shows the XPS spectra of Co 2p and O1s orbitals of the catalysts. The peaks with binding energies (BEs) at 795.3 and 780.2 eV are assigned to Co2p1/2 and Co2p3/2 orbitals of Co3+ species (Fig. 5a), respectively. The peaks with BEs at 797.0 and 781.9 eV are attributed to Co2p1/2 and Co2p3/2 orbitals of Co2+ species, respectively [28–31]. The shake-up satellites peaks of cobalt oxides could be observed near BEs at 785.0–790.0 eV and 803.0–804.0 eV. Based on the peak fitting, the ratio of Co3+/(Co2+ + Co3+) is calculated as listed in Table 3. The surface concentrations of Co3+ species are in the order of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A (66.1%) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B (64.0%) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C (57.2%) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 (55.9%). In Fig. 5b, the peak with BE at 532.6 eV is corresponding to lattice oxygen species (Oa) in ZSM-5 support, and the peak with binding energy of 531.3 eV can be assigned to the adsorbed oxygen species or OH species (Ob), while the peak appearing at 530 eV is attributed to surface lattice O2− of Co3O4 (Oc) [21,32,33]. Lattice oxygen species in ZSM-5 support (Oa, 532.6 eV) exhibits much higher binding energy compared to that of Co3O4 species (Oc, 530 eV). Besides, it can be seen that 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst shows the highest ratio of Oc/Ob (2.1) in Table 3, whereas 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst shows the lowest ratio (0.38). Fig. 6 a shows the H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts.There are two reduction peaks (α and β) in the profiles. The reduction peak α at 370–380 °C is assigned to the reduction of Co3+ species (Co2O3 → CoO), while the reduction peak β above 400 °C can be attributed to the reduction of Co2+ species (CoO → Co) [30,34]. 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A gives the lowest reduction temperature of Co3+ at 370 °C, suggesting the highest reducibility of surface lattice O2− in Co3O4 species. The area ratios of peak α/β are analyzed and the ratios follow the order of 5Co3O4/ZSM-5-A (0.343) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B (0.331) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C (0.325) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 (0.318). The ratio of Co3+/(Co2+ + Co3+) in the these catalysts can be calculated by the following expression: C o 2 O 3 + H 2 → 2 CoO + H 2 O ( α peak area ) CoO + H 2 → Co + H 2 O ( β peak area , the reduction of total C o 2 + including from reduced C o 3 + ) C o 3 + / ( C o 3 + + C o 2 + ) = 2 α peak area / ( β peak area ) Thus, the ratio of Co3+/(Co3+ + Co2+) can be obtained: 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A (68.6%) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B (66.2%) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C (65.0%) > 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 (63.6%). The tendency of ratio of Co3+/(Co3+ + Co2+) in these catalysts is consistent with the result of XPS, namely, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst possesses the highest content of Co3+ species. Whereas, XPS gives the surface signal and H2-TPR gives the bulk signal, thus, there are some differences in the ratios obtained by these two methods. In Fig. 6b, the signals in EPR profiles can be attributed to the Co2+ species which contain the single electron. The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst exhibited the stronger signal than the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst when the equivalent catalyst was used in test, indicating more Co2+ species but less Co3+ species in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst. This result is consistent with the XPS and H2-TPR results, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst possesses more Co3+ species, suggesting more surface lattice O2− of Co3O4 species in the catalyst. 3.3 Discussion on the enhanced activity of Co3O4/ZSM-5-A The above characterizations demonstrated that the surface Co3O4 active species of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst can be restructured by pre-reduction and pre-oxidation treatment as briefly described in Scheme 1 . The enhanced activity of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst can be explained as following. Firstly, the size of surface Co3O4 active species in 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 can be modulated by pre-reduction and pre-oxidation treatment. Compared to the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst has smaller size of Co3O4 species, indicating its more exposed active sites for catalytic propane combustion. Thus, the remarkable size change of Co3O4 species should be one of the reasons for improving catalytic activity observed on the Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. Secondly, in-situ DRIFT spectra were conducted to investigate the reaction mechanism of propane combustion over the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts, although the mechanism of propane oxidation reaction occurring over Co3O4 based catalysts are well known as Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism [20,21,35,36]: Fig. 7 shows the in-situ DRIFT spectra of sequential propane adsorption, propane oxidation and N2 purge over the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts at 280 °C. For the pure C3H8 atmosphere, the bands at 2850–3000 cm−1 are assigned to the gaseous propane [8,20]. The bands at around 2300 cm−1 are attributed to gaseous CO2, which were generated from the propane oxidation by surface lattice O2- of Co3O4 species. This observation confirms the Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism for propane oxidation over the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts. C o 3 O 4 _ O * + C 3 H 8 → R − C o 3 O 4 + C O 2 + H 2 O R − C o 3 O 4 + O 2 → C o 3 O 4 _ O * (O* represents surface lattice O2−species in Co3O4; R-Co3O4 represents the reduced Co3O4 by propane) The surface lattice oxygen of Co3O4 based catalyst is firstly reduced by propane and then regenerate by being oxidized with O2. Compared to the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst shows weaker bands of gaseous propane and strong bands of gaseous CO2, suggesting its faster reaction rate of propane oxidation. Combined with the above characterizations, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst has more content of Co3+ species and surface lattice O2−species, which is responsible for its faster reaction rate. Furthermore, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst shows highest reducibility of surface lattice O2−species in the H2-TPR profile, which also promotes its propane oxidation through Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism. For the C3H8 + O2 atmosphere, the decreased gaseous propane bands and increased gaseous CO2 bands are observed for both the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts, which is attributed to the accelerated reaction rate of propane oxidation due to the presence of O2. Besides, some weak bands appear at 1700–1900 cm−1, implying the formation of surface carbonate species [6,8,39]. These surface carbonate species are generally regarded as the intermediates during the propane oxidation process, which would be easily decomposed as evidenced by the N2 purge process. In addition, a negative bands at 3729 cm−1 can be attributed to the consumption of surface hydroxyl groups on the catalyst surface. And the surface hydroxyl groups could be rapidly recovered as also evidenced by the N2 purge process. Another question need to be answered is that why the Co3O4 catalyst shows lower catalytic activity than the Co3O4/ZSM-5 and Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts (Fig. 1c), although Co3O4 catalyst has more surface lattice O2- (Fig. 5b). It seems to that the ZSM-5 support also play a very important role on catalysis of the Co3O4/ZSM-5 and Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. Thus, the role of support should also be considered. Actually, the natures of support has also been widely discussed on improving catalytic activity, such as surface acidity, oxygen species, etc [5,12,39]. For instance, the acid sites are often regarded as the crucial active sites for long chain alkane activation [37]. Fig. 8 shows the NH3-TPD profiles of the Co3O4 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts. The Co3O4 catalyst gives limited acid sites, whereas there are abundant acid sites in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 due to the presence of ZSM-5 support. The acid sites remain after the preparation of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. It is inferred that the acid sites are responsible for the higher activities of propane oxidation over 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts compared to Co3O4 catalysts. 3.4 Kinetic investigation of propane oxidation To further understand the different catalytic behaviors between the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts, Fig. 9 shows the kinetics and apparent activation energies of these two catalysts for propane combustion. The ratios of C3H8/O2 were controlled from 1/7.5 to 1/45. Mass and heat transfer limitations were excluded by the calculation of Weisz-Prater and Mears’ criterion [38,39] and the detail data are given in Supporting Information (Tables S2 and S3). The reaction rates of propane combustion would increase with increasing propane partial pressure, whereas the reaction rates obviously decrease when the O2 partial pressure increases for both the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts. The corresponding parameters of kinetics are listed in Table 4 , and the derived power law rate expressions are r = 8.3 × 10−6 [C3H8]0.63[O2]−0.35 for the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst, and r = 11.2 × 10−6 [C3H8]0.72[O2]−0.52 for the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. Firstly, the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst shows a much higher apparent rate constant k than that of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst, implying the faster reaction rate occurring over the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. Secondly, the reaction orders of propane are positive for both the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts, which are 0.63 and 0.72, respectively. This observation indicates the medium intensity adsorption of propane on these two catalysts. The reaction orders of oxygen are negative for both the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 and 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts, suggesting the inhibition effect of the increased oxygen partial pressure on the catalytic activity. This observation can be attributed to the competitive adsorption of oxygen with propane. More remarkable inhibition effect of the increasing oxygen partial pressure on the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst activity may be ascribed to the stronger oxygen adsorption or weaker propane adsorption on the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst, which could be related to the surface property change of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst compared to the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst, such as the content of surface lattice O2− and Co3+. Thirdly, although the propane oxidation reaction obeys Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism over the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst and the surface lattice O2−species of Co3O4 catalyst would participate in the reaction, the reaction order of gaseous O2 is negative order rather than zero because of the competitive adsorption of gaseous O2 with propane on the sites for propane activation. The apparent activation energy of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst (Ea = 37.1 ± 2.9 kJ mol−1) is much lower than that of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst (Ea = 85.5 ± 6.7 kJ mol−1), indicating the easier occurrence of propane oxidation over the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. The higher reducibility and more content of lattice O2− in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst facilitated the catalytic reaction, which is evidenced by the higher catalytic activity observed on the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. 4 Conclusion The catalytic activities of Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalysts for propane combustion were significantly enhanced after pre-reduction and pre-oxidation (labeled as Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalysts). Both the content of Co3O4 and the acid sites of ZSM-5 support have remarkable effect on the catalytic activity for propane combustion. The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst shows the highest reaction rate of 0.379 μmol gcat −1 s−1. And the Ea of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst (Ea = 37.1 ± 2.9 kJ mol−1) is much lower than that of 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst (Ea = 85.5 ± 6.7 kJ mol−1). The increased contents of both Co3+ species and surface lattice O2− of Co3O4 species in the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst are mainly responsible for the enhanced catalytic activity of propane combustion through the Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism. This work provides an novel method to tailor the efficient Co3O4 active sites for propane combustion. coredata.dc:description: Co3O4 species in Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst can be tailored to smaller particle size and higher content of surface lattice O2− and Co3+ species by pre-reduction and pre-oxidation (labeled as Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst), resulting in the enhanced catalytic activity for propane combustion. The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst gives a high reaction rate of 0.379 μmol gcat −1 s−1, which is over two folds higher than that of the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst (reaction rate of only 0.177 μmol gcat −1 s−1). The higher content and reducibility of surface lattice O2− in the Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst facilitated its activity for propane combustion through the Mars-Van Krevelen mechanism as evidenced by in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectra. The 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst (Ea = 37.1 ± 2.9 kJ mol−1) gives much lower apparent activation energy than 25Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst (Ea = 85.5 ± 6.7 kJ mol−1), suggesting the easier occurrence of propane combustion over the 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A catalyst. The atmospheres (2% O2 + 0.2% C3H8 + N2; 9% O2 + 0.2% C3H8 + N2; Air) for pre-oxidation process also significantly affect the catalytic activity of the finally obtained catalysts (labeled as 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-A, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-B, 25Co3O4/ZSM-5-C), which is attributed to their differences in Co3O4 species (nanoparticle size, and the content of surface lattice O2− and Co3+). Besides, the acid sites of ZSM-5 also play important role on the catalytic combustion propane.
coredata.dc:title: Tailoring Co3O4 active species to promote propane combustion over Co3O4/ZSM-5 catalyst
